roleset.name: signal, convey
roleset.note: MEAN-V NOTES: Frames file for 'mean' based on survey of initial sentences of big corpus. Split from mean.02 (old mean.01) which wasunable to capture conveyance of meaning. Member of VN classrepresentation-110. (from mean.01-v predicate notes)
MEANING-N NOTES: Roleset based on verb entry mean.02. (from meaning.01-n)

example.name: mean-v: resulted in
example.text: Huge gains by her students in 1987 and 1988 meant a total of $5000 in bonuses over two years.
example.arg: Huge gains by her students in 1987 and 1988
a total of $5000 in bonuses over two years.

example.name: mean-v: this means that
example.text: The leeway that Sea Containers has means that Temple would have to substantially increase their bid.
example.arg: The leeway that Sea Containers has
that Temple would have to substantially increase their bid.

example.name: mean-v: with ARG2
example.text: What-1 a Lien victory means *T*-1 for the New Party.

example.name: meaning-n: resulted in
example.text: The name Melchizedek , king of Salem , also has a meaning "King of Righteousness".
example.arg: The name Melchizedek , king of Salem ,

example.name: mean-v: arg0
example.text: What T-1 do you mean by that *-1?

example.name: mean-v: again, seperate agent and conveyer
example.text: I don't mean anything by that.

example.name: mean-v: volitional and intentional = agent
example.text: I mean that you look silly in that hat.
example.arg: that you look silly in that hat.

example.name: mean-v: non-agentive, non-volitional conveyer of meaning
example.text: A wagging tail means the dog is happy.

roleset.name: intend
roleset.note: MEAN-V NOTES: Frames file for 'mean' based on survey of initial sentences of big corpus. Member of VN class intend-61.2-1. Youshould be able to replace the verb with 'intend' for this sense.

example.name: mean-v: with beneficiary
example.text: The letter was meant for him.

example.name: mean-v: action intended to be completed

roleset.name: stingy, meager
roleset.note: MEAN-J NOTES: Added by Julia. (from mean.02-j)

example.name: mean-j: both args
example.text: He was mean with his money-- waiting for him to get his round in was not really an option-- but he was incredibly generous withhis time.

example.name: mean-j: arg 1
example.text: Everybody was very thirsty and hungry as the rations were mean.

roleset.name: mean, unkind
roleset.note: MEAN-J NOTES: Updated by Julia based on BOLT-6. (from mean.01-j)

example.name: mean-j: Mean Girls, all args
example.text: She was mean to the girl who answered all the questions.
example.arg: to the girl who answered all the questions

roleset.name: intend, explain, is equivalent to
roleset.note: MEANINGFUL-J NOTES: Automatically created by Julia as an alias file for unification. (from meaningful.01-j)

role.descr: agent, element containing or conveying meaning

example.name: meaningful-j
example.text: The change in pain intensity that-1 *-1 is meaningful to patients increases as the severity of their baseline pain increases.
